image.altText: Black-and-white picture of Ben Aulich.

props.synopsis: Former Canberra criminal lawyer Ben Aulich will stand trial after allegedly talking with an undercover police officer about setting up a supermarket to launder money from illegal cigarette sales.

title.children: Former Canberra lawyer to stand trial for allegedly conspiring to launder money

image.altText: Law Courts of the Australian Capital Territory

props.synopsis: The 38-year-old man was charged with two counts of sexual assault after a picnic with the alleged victim at a secluded spot at the Cotter Reserve just outside Canberra in 2020.

title.children: Jury fails to reach verdict in trial of former PhD student who allegedly 'love-bombed' and raped woman

image.altText: A male choir rehearses. There are two lines of men, with one line standing on a stop behind the others.

props.synopsis: The Canberra Men's Choir is an "awesome fellowship" and no auditions are required.

title.children: Retirement can be a 'trap' for men. So these blokes joined a choir

image.altText: A copy of Mem Fox's book Where is the Green Sheep? stands alongside copies of its commemorative coin.

props.synopsis: Classic children's book written by Mem Fox and illustrated by Judy Horacek gets commemorated on 20-cent coin.

title.children: Where is the green sheep? On a 20-cent coin

image.altText: Protesters sit down and chant at the Australian National University pro-Palestine encampment.

props.synopsis: The ANU has announced it will no longer invest in certain weapons companies in the long term, following months of pressure from pro-Palestinian student groups.

title.children: ANU to stop long-term investments in 'controversial' weapons manufacturers following months-long Gaza protest on campus

props.synopsis: Canberra Health Services said it received a "lot of feedback" on the post and had removed it for fear of it being "misinterpreted". It will now meet with members of a Canberra endometriosis support group who expressed concern about the messaging.

title.children: Apology issued after endometriosis, arthritis described as 'not an emergency' in hospital's social video

image.altText: A small group of people walk along a city street as a photographer paps them.

props.synopsis: The parents of former defence minister Linda Reynolds tell a WA court their daughter was viewed as a "monster" and they were shunned by friends after Brittany Higgins's explosive interview on Channel 10's the Project.

title.children: 'Accused of being a monster': Linda Reynolds's parents hit out in Brittany Higgins court battle

image.altText: A close up of a woman looking out a window.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton's call for a temporary ban on accepting Palestinian refugees from Gaza has fuelled government accusations he is dividing the community.

title.children: Independent MP who fled war says debate over Gaza refugee ban is 'triggering', as Peter Dutton doubles down

image.altText: Melbourne CBD people retail shopping

props.synopsis: The unemployment rate climbs to 4.2 per cent in July, with data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics showing more than 58,000 jobs were created last month.

title.children: Unemployment rate climbs to 4.2 per cent in July with more than 58,000 jobs created

image.altText: Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

props.synopsis: The latest outbreak of mpox is different to the one that spread around the world in 2022 — and has experts on high alert

title.children: Mpox is now a global health emergency. Here's what that means for Australia

image.altText: Macron and Aliyev.

props.synopsis: A Pacific archipelago in Australia's backyard has become a new front in a bitter feud between France and Azerbaijan.

title.children: How a tourist mecca off Australia's coast got entangled in France's feud with an enemy

image.altText: Anthony Albanese confused in QT

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton trade barbs over what Australia's spy boss is saying about Gaza visa applications as the fallout continues over the opposition leader's remarks. Follow live.

title.children: PM accused of misquoting top spy, Dutton told to 'stop being racist'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Dutton hits back at Zali Steggall
CFMEU vote to go ahead today
Tensions bubble over in the corridors of Parliament House

image.altText: A man looks at the camera with a neutral expression. Behind him a canal and a restaurant are visible.

props.synopsis: A "hero" security guard who tackled a knife-wielding man and freed the young Australian girl he'd been stabbing in a London shop has been honoured for his bravery.

title.children: A man wielding a knife attacked an 11yo Aussie girl in London. Then Abdullah 'jumped on the guy'

image.altText: A close up of Yahya Sinwa at a rally among a crowd of people.

props.synopsis: Three senior Iranian officials have said that only a ceasefire deal in Gaza would hold Iran back from direct retaliation against Israel for the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh.

title.children: Hamas to stay out of Gaza truce talks but may meet mediators afterwards

image.altText: A teacher is seen at the front of a primary school classroom

props.synopsis: Upwey South Primary School's academic results have lifted dramatically over the past six years. The principal puts it down to a shift in teaching styles.

title.children: This public school's academic results have skyrocketed over the past six years. Here's how they did it

image.altText: A full moon is seen through clouds above Stonehenge

props.synopsis: The Altar Stone, long believed to have come from Wales, may have been transported via sea from Scotland, according to new research from an Australian team.

title.children: 'Completely unexpected': Stonehenge's central stone may have come from 700km away, new research suggests

image.altText: A medieval man holds a phone with the Sportsbet logo displayed.

props.synopsis: Changes to gambling advertising won't happen until next month at the earliest as the government scrambles to manage a caucus pushback and resistance from the crossbenches.

title.children: Government pushes back gambling advertising reforms, tussling over internal resistance

image.altText: News presenter Bridget Brennan stands at a desk in a TV studio, smiling. She is wearing a pink dress.

props.synopsis: Bridget Brennan will be the new co-host of ABC News Breakfast, taking over from Lisa Millar when she farewells the show in late August.

title.children: 'An important moment for my mob': Bridget Brennan to co-host ABC News Breakfast

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The ASX200 jumps higher after US inflation falls below 3 per cent, but Telstra profits are down 12.8 per cent. There are signs Australia's economy is continuing to contract, with a jump in the employment rate.

title.children: Unemployment rises, ASX200 jumps higher after US inflation declines, Telstra profits down 12.8 per cent

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Government to guarantee Rex flight bookings for next month
Which US politician can win over crypto voters?
The economy is slowing, but RBA will want to see it slow more: economist

image.altText: Sunita Williams and Butch WIlmore

props.synopsis: NASA officials said they're analysing more data before making a decision by end of next week or beginning of the next.

title.children: NASA still deciding whether to keep stranded astronauts at space station until next year

image.altText: A young boy dances in front of the Camps Breakerz studio in the Nuseirat refugee camp in the Gaza Strip.

props.synopsis: In the middle of a war zone in Gaza, children are performing breakdancing flips and jumps between the rubble. Meet the breakdancing crew keeping hope alive.

title.children: 'Breaking can heal trauma': Children in Gaza breakdance to hold on to hope

image.altText: Two soldiers sit on top of a small tank, driving in front of a second small tank, on a deserted road.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said more than 100 Russian soldiers had been captured as prisoners of war, to "speed up the return home of our boys and girls".

title.children: Ukrainian forces 'moving further' into Russia as more than 100 soldiers captured, Zelenskyy says

image.altText: Saline drip

props.synopsis: Patients are having to stay in hospital for longer periods and some elective surgeries face delays because of a global shortage of intravenous fluids, which doctors say they have been left "in the dark" about.

title.children: Patients forced to stay in hospital care units for longer amid IV fluid shortage

image.altText: A girl in school uniform shows a phone to two boys in uniform.

props.synopsis: In public schools across Australia, kids are getting used to phone bans — and politicians are spruiking big improvements in student behaviour. But not everyone is convinced.

title.children: Mobile phones are now banned in public schools across Australia. Here's how kids think it's going

image.altText: A close up of a woman holding a phone to her face.

props.synopsis: A former police officer thought she would have the edge in dealing with scammers. She was shocked when she found out she had fallen prey to a sophisticated bank fraud scheme.

title.children: Ex-cop scammed as fraudster beats two-factor authentication process

image.altText: Star trails over land and water

props.synopsis: Sink into your chair and prepare your brain for a battle with knowledge. With questions ranging from the Moon to Sirius and celestial gems outside our galaxy, this quiz will stretch the boundaries of your mind.

title.children: Think you're pretty night-sky-smart? Take our star-crossed quiz to find out

image.altText: Close up of a glass jar containing blue ring shaped lollies

props.synopsis: Police in Perth charge a 16-year-old boy with manufacturing a batch of cannabis-laced gummies and selling them to a 16-year-old girl, who then fell ill along with another female student after the pair ingested them.

title.children: Cannabis lollies allegedly made and sold by WA schoolboy leave two fellow students in hospital

image.altText: Jayson Gillham smiles and looks away from the camera in this professional portrait photo

props.synopsis: A concert featuring Australian-British pianist Jayson Gillham is set to be rescheduled after the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra says it made an "error" in cancelling his performance following comments he made about the killing of journalists in Gaza.

title.children: Melbourne Symphony Orchestra says it made 'error' in cancelling pianist's performance after Gaza comments

image.altText: A colour drawing of a baseballer standing in the batter's box, pointing his bat down the middle of the field.

props.synopsis: The record price for a piece of sports memorabilia is set to be smashed in the United States, with a World Series shirt worn by baseball great Babe Ruth already drawing huge bids for an auction later this month.

title.children: 'Like buying the Mona Lisa': Babe Ruth 'called shot' jersey could smash record at auction

image.altText: An e-scooter stands on a footpath.

props.synopsis: Experts say the City of Melbourne's snap decision to end its share hire e-scooter scheme is sending shock waves around the country, as states decide whether the vehicles are worth the safety risk.

title.children: Melbourne's decision to ban share hire e-scooters could send 'shock waves' to other Australian cities

image.altText: Four pineapple flavoured sweets in a yellow wrapped which actually contain meth

props.synopsis: Police recover nearly 30 blocks of the drug disguised as branded lollies and say circulation appears to be within the Auckland region.

title.children: Meth lollies distributed by New Zealand food bank 'likely from a smuggling operation gone wrong'

image.altText: Boxer Imane Khelif connects with a straight left-hand punch to her opponent's head

props.synopsis: French prosecutors open an investigation into an online harassment complaint made by Olympic boxing champion Imane Khelif after a torrent of criticism and false claims about her gender during the Paris Games.

title.children: French prosecutors investigate gender-based cyber harassment of Paris Olympic champ Khelif

image.altText: Two people wearing masks and gloves look at a row of dead birds.

props.synopsis: Millions of birds and mammals have already died across the world but the deadly H5N1 strain of bird flu is yet to reach Australia or its Antarctic territories. A team is preparing for when, not if, that happens.

title.children: Australian Antarctic scientists wargame for spread of deadly H5N1
